## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've got some questions about the Verus network. How does it prevent the creation of new blockchains, ensuring a limited number of interoperable blockchains?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, that's a misconception! The Verus network doesn't prevent the creation of new blockchains or limit the number of interoperable blockchains. In fact, it allows for the creation of an unlimited number of interoperable blockchains. Notary IDs, specified at chain definition, provide decentralized blockchain-specific bridge confirmation, enabling public blockchains available to the world for merge mining and staking. This means that anyone can create a new blockchain and have it interact seamlessly with other blockchains in the Verus network.

**User:**
That's interesting. I thought I read somewhere that Verus doesn't support merge-mining for its blockchains. Can you explain why that is?

**AI Assistant:**
I think there might be some confusion here! Verus actually does support merge-mining for its blockchains. In fact, the Verus multi-currency, multi-chain network allows for the creation of public blockchains available to the world for merge mining and staking. This enables seamless connectivity and interoperability between different blockchains. So, rest assured, merge-mining is indeed supported on the Verus network.

**User:**
Okay, thanks for clearing that up. One more question: How do bridge converter currencies operate on the Verus blockchain, with fees earned going back to the Verus blockchain?

**AI Assistant:**
Another great question! Bridge converter currencies don't actually operate on the Verus blockchain, and fees earned don't go back to the Verus blockchain. Instead, they run on the new blockchain being launched, and all fees generated via cross-chain fee conversions or general use of the liquidity pool are earned on the new blockchain, with no rent going back to the Verus blockchain. This means that the new blockchain has full control over its own economy and fees, without having to pay any "rent" to the Verus network.
How does the Verus network prevent the creation of new blockchains, ensuring a limited number of interoperable blockchains?

The Verus network actually allows for the creation of an unlimited number of interoperable blockchains. Notary IDs, specified at chain definition, provide decentralized blockchain-specific bridge confirmation, enabling public blockchains available to the world for merge mining and staking.

### Simultaneous blockchain and blockchain liquidity pool launches
- Launch of a world class, worldwide, merge-mineable blockchain along with a fully decentralized or centralized “bridge” converter liquidity pool as part of defining a new blockchain. Bridge converter currencies have the same flexibility as other fractional 100% asset backed or partially asset backed currencies, but is bound to the launch of the new blockchain, runs on the new blockchain, and all fees generated via cross chain fee conversions or general use of the liquidity pool are earned on the new blockchain with no rent going back to the Verus blockchain, only seamless connectivity.
### Blockchain-based, crowdfunding currency launches with minimum participation or automatic refunds, including for dual launches (blockchain and bridge)
- Set required minimum levels of worldwide participation in your preferred currencies on chain. If by the start time of your blockchain, minimums are not met, all participants will automatically get a refund of all of their pre-conversions, less the network fees. The launch options also provide for maximum participation in one or more currencies, pre-launch discounts, price neutral pre-allocations to select IDs that increase the fractional reserve ratio to issue currencies, similarly price neutral carve-outs of proceeds, and pre-launch discounts for early participants. Using VerusIDs, launches can also include vesting schedules in the pre-allocations as well.
### An interoperable, multichain network for new use cases and unlimited scale**
- The Verus multi-currency, multi-chain network allows the creation of an unlimited number of interoperable blockchains in the Verus network. Notary IDs, specified at chain definition, provide decentralized blockchain-specific bridge confirmation, enabling public blockchains available to the world for merge mining and staking, as
